title.narrative: Watershed Mali - WI

description.narrative: Improved governance of the WASH/IWRM sector, responsive to the interests of marginalised groups.
Integrated Water Resource Management including Sanitation and Hygiene

Sustainable Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) services through Integrated Water Resource Management (IWRM) is the ultimate goal of Watershed. Where water insecurity threatens or coincides with weak WASH services, the partnership will seek to connect all water users and stakeholders— central and local governments, the media, the private sector, research and academic institutions, utilities, CSOs and networks.. The role of ecosystems in safeguarding the availability of raw water and cleansing used water will be emphasised.
Watershed will ensure that evidence, knowledge and lessons from district-scale interventions are translated upwards to influence governance and policy at national, regional and international levels. Change in policy and practice will be achieved by evidence-based lobbying and advocacy by Watershed partner organisations and civil society organisations (CSOs) in the target countries.

Wetland community in Mali, credit:
CSO 8. - CSOs hold service providers accountable
CSO 8. - <Partner 1> Level of use of reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy

description.narrative: 100% - CSOs are holding government WASH and IWRM service providers to account successfully 75% - CSOs are holding service providers to account regarding sustainable and inclusive WASH / IWRM 50% - CSOs have planned concrete actions on how they will hold service providers to account regarding sustainable and inclusive WASH / IWRM (for example by tracking the inclusiveness and sustainability of WASH and IWRM services) 25% - CSOs know how to hold service providers to account regarding sustainable and inclusive WASH / IWRM 0% - CSOs are not holding service providers (government and/or private sector) to account regarding sustainable and inclusive WASH / IWRM

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: RJEPA: This level is also stagnant (50%). Efforts are ongoing to implement common strategies to hold service providers and local governments to account. But the higher level is still a challenge. CN-CIEPA: Activities have just started and focused only on the sharing of information on the Watershed project, the identification of the actors and their training.

title.narrative: CSO 6. - CSOs integrate IWRM-WASH in their L&A activities
CSO 6. - <Partner 1> Level of integration of WASH-IWRM in L&A

description.narrative: 100% - CSOs convince their targets from both WASH and IWRM sectors to collaborate on themes/issues relevant for the CSOs constituency 75% - CSOs have integrated strategies and specific L&A messages for WASH and IWRM sectors 50% - CSOs are engaged in L&A about the same theme/issue with targets (in government and/or private sector) from both the WASH and IWRM sectors 25% - CSOs are aware that sustainable WASH is dependent on proper water resource management 0% - CSOs do not understand the relation between WASH and IWRM

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: At the current stage, CSOs have a strong understanding of the importance of integrating WASH-GIRE but need to be strengthened to work with the concept and the integration methodology for an effective L & P.

title.narrative: Gov 10. -Government generates reliable data on WASH and IWRM services beyond functionality of facilities (water availability, water quality, pollution of water sources, waste management, reliability of services, consumer satisfaction,...)
GOV - 10 <partner 1> Level of Government monitoring of WASH and IWRM services

description.narrative: 100% - Government uses reliable data on WASH and IWRM services to improve quality of services 75% - Government makes reliable data on WASH and IWRM services available 50% - Government generates reliable data on WASH and IWRM services 25% - Government understands the importance of generating reliable data on WASH and IWRM services (functionality of WASH facilities, water availability, water quality,...) 0% - Government does not monitor WASH and IWRM services (functionality of WASH facilities, water availability, water quality,...)

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: The government has data on WASH and IWRM, but the reliability of this data remains to be desired, as well as their availability to the public. Data are not updated and monitoring of WASH services (work, water quality, etc.) is not done regularly. The National Directorate of Hydraulics (DNH) and the DNACPN are separate structures that hold separate data: IWRM and water quality data by DNH and sanitation data are held by DNACPN. As a result, WASH GIRE integration is a challenge.

title.narrative: GOV - 10 <partner 2> Level of Government monitoring of WASH and IWRM services

description.narrative: 100% - Government uses reliable data on WASH and IWRM services to improve quality of services 75% - Government makes reliable data on WASH and IWRM services available 50% - Government generates reliable data on WASH and IWRM services 25% - Government understands the importance of generating reliable data on WASH and IWRM services (functionality of WASH facilities, water availability, water quality,...) 0% - Government does not monitor WASH and IWRM services (functionality of WASH facilities, water availability, water quality,...)

title.narrative: Gov 7. -Local Government is transparent about expenditure on WASH/IWRM
GOV - 7 <partner 1> Level of transparency in expenditure by Local Government

description.narrative: 100% - Local Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM and requesting feedback from civil society 75% - Local Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 50% - Local Government is planning how to practise transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 25% - Local Government is aware of the importance of transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 0% - Local Government do not practise transparency in expenditures on WASH and IWRM

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: In a sample of 10 municipalities, it emerged from discussion that 7 out of 10 local governments are aware of the importance of budget transparency but not of transparency in spending. For example in Macina: the population including CSOs, state technical services and NGOs are invited to public sessions on the district budget that the town hall organizes each year, but this is not the case for district expenses. The actors present who discussed this scale: CAEB, CN-CIEPA, counsellor of Macina, Akvo, WI, RJEPA.

title.narrative: GOV - 7 <partner 2> Level of transparency in expenditure by Local Government

description.narrative: 100% - Local Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM and requesting feedback from civil society 75% - Local Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 50% - Local Government is planning how to practise transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 25% - Local Government is aware of the importance of transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 0% - Local Government do not practise transparency in expenditures on WASH and IWRM

title.narrative: Gov 6. -National Government is transparent about expenditure on WASH/IWRM
GOV - 6 <partner 1> Level of transparency in expenditure by National Government

description.narrative: 100% - National Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM and requesting feedback from civil society 75% - National Government is practising transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 50% - National Government is planning how to practise transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 25% - National Government is aware of the importance of transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM 0% - National Government do not have transparency in expenditure on WASH and IWRM

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: The 25% level is maintained as the base scale for a target of 75%. The national government observes social changes where people do not accept just everything anymore and ask for transparency. So, also at the national level we are making efforts of transparency, but no concrete actions in this direction as yet.

title.narrative: CSO 3. - CSOs collaborate with other CSOs for effective lobby and advocacy
CSO 3. - <partner 1> Level of collaboration with other CSOs for effective lobby and advocacy

description.narrative: 100% -CSOs’ strategic partnership increases the weight of the voice of CSOs in lobby and advocacy for sustainable WASH for all 75% - CSOs are collaborating strategically with other CSOs in lobby and advocacy for sustainable WASH for all 50% - CSOs are engaged in discussions toward strategic collaboration with other CSOs 25% - CSOs are aware of the importance to collaborate with other CSOs 0% - CSOs work in isolation

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: RJEPA: For WASH there is good collaboration between CSOs. For IWRM, CSO engagement is lower due to lack of interest from strategic and financial partners. The network of journalists for IWRM had been established but could not evolve due to insufficient resources. CN-CIEPA: At the current stage, we estimate a score increase from 25 to 50% because the activities (identification, training, exchanges ...) were undertaken in the all the intervention zones of the project and allowed for appropriation of and adherence to the objectives of the project. CAEB: CSOs collaborate with others, CAEB is a member of the Wash Alliance Mali, which groups more than ten local CSOs.

title.narrative: CSO 1. - CSOs use reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy
CSO 1. - <Partner 1> Level of use of reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy

description.narrative: 100% - CSOs convince their target groups with reliable evidence 75% - CSOs use reliable evidence to base lobby and advocacy strategies and messages on 50% - CSOs partner with relevant stakeholders to identify and fill gaps in reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy 25% - CSOs are aware of the importance to use reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy 0% - CSOs are not aware of reliable evidence for lobby and advocacy

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: On average the baseline score of 50% is maintained relative to the 75% target (which was originally set at 100% in February 2017). RJEPA thinks that this situation is stagnant as the project has started gathering evidence on water quality and waste management but they are not yet well organized to use data appropriately in the development of strategies and messages. CN-CIEPA / WASH also maintains the score at 50%. Because the activities just started, they focused – rather than on production of evidence - on the sharing of information on the project, the identification of the actors, their training and the analysis of policies incl. the inventory of policy violations. CAEB maintains its score at 50% because the project has not yet generated evidence but actually does more analysis and information gathering. CN-CIEPA / WASH also maintains the score at 50%. Because the activities just started, they focused – rather than on production of evidence - on the sharing of information on the project, the identification of the actors, their training and the analysis of policies incl. the inventory of policy violations. CAEB maintains its score at 50% against the 75% target for the reasons that the project itself has not yet generated evidence but actually does more analysis and information gathering. On average the baseline score of 50% is maintained relative to the 75% target ( which was set at 100% in February 2017)

title.narrative: Gov 4. <partner 1> National Government allocates budget transparently to WASH/IWRM
GOV - 4: Level of transparency in budget allocation by National Government

description.narrative: 100% - National Government coordinates joint (inclusive, sustainable) sector budget allocation 75% - National Government supports dialogue on (inclusive, sustainable) sector budget allocation 50% - National Government is practising transparent (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation 25% - National Government is aware of the importance of transparency in (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation 0% - National Government does not have transparency in (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation

comment.narrative: 26-06-2018: The indicator fell from 50% to 25% for a target of 75% (desired value). Nevertheless, there is an effort to include civil society actors in the process such as the Sustainable Wash Alliance which advocates for more budget allocated to the WASH sector. It is noted that only 0.8% of the national budget is allocated to the WASH sector which is literally too low to cover access for all to a sustainable Wash.

title.narrative: Gov 4. <partner 2> National Government allocates budget transparently to WASH/IWRM

description.narrative: 100% - National Government coordinates joint (inclusive, sustainable) sector budget allocation 75% - National Government supports dialogue on (inclusive, sustainable) sector budget allocation 50% - National Government is practising transparent (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation 25% - National Government is aware of the importance of transparency in (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation 0% - National Government does not have transparency in (inclusive, sustainable) budget allocation
